Line: Paul Ryan went on offense Tuesday in response to criticism over his Medicare plan, using an interview with Fox News coupled with a new TV ad to claim President Obama's health care plan treats the treasured entitlement like a  piggy bank,  while the  Romney-Ryan  plan preserves it.
Label: Informational

Line: Ryan, in his first one-on-one interview since being named Saturday as Mitt Romney's running mate, told Fox News on Tuesday he thinks Medicare can be a winning issue for their campaign.
Label: Neutral

Line: "We're the ones who are offering a plan to save Medicare, to protect Medicare, to strengthen Medicare," Ryan said.
Label: Neutral

Line: "We're the ones who are not raiding Medicare to pay for ObamaCare.

Label: Neutral

Line: And we want to point that out.
Label: Neutral

Line: And we want to ' restore those cuts to prevent that raid.

Label: Neutral

Line: That's a clear contrast with President Obama's plan.

Line: Both sides are being selective in how they describe each other's plans.

Line: The Ryan proposal, submitted again in the House earlier this year, would a decade from now give seniors government payments to purchase private plans or stay within the current system.

Line: Ryan says this is to preserve Medicare, not  end  it, as Obama's campaign claims.

Line: Though he doesn't use the word  cuts,  the plan would slow the rate of benefit growth for seniors according to the Congressional Budget Office.

Line: And the ObamaCare cuts he referenced would likely come in the form of lower payments to providers.

Line: WASHINGTON -- In the wake of Mitt Romney's choice of Paul Ryan as his vice presidential nominee, the politics of Medicare have become almost as complicated as the policy itself.
Label: Neutral

Line: The most recent back-and-forth between the Romney and Obama campaigns concerns which candidate would do more harm to people's benefits.
Label: Neutral

Line: While the president's team has pointed to the Republican plan to turn Medicare into a quasi-voucher program -- in which recipients would receive a check to buy either insurance through the private market or traditional Medicare -- the Romney team has responded by noting that Obama took more than $700 billion out of Medicare as part of his health care overhaul.
Label: Neutral

Line: "He stole $700 billion from Medicare to fund Obamacare," said RNC Chair Reince Priebus.

Line: That rejoinder is now a subject of intense debate.

Line: The money being taken out of the system by the Affordable Care Act is mostly derived from limiting the expected rate of growth in the program.

Line: As such, independent fact-checkers and news analysts alike have disputed the Romney campaign's characterization.

Label: Lexical

Label: Neutral

Line: Douglas Holtz-Eakin, McCain's policy director at the time, recalled that the attack originated with a Wall Street Journal article that referenced his saying that McCain would assume savings in Medicare and Medicaid spending to make his health care plan budget neutral.

Line: Those savings were expected to come from eliminating fraud and reforming payment policies.

Line: Holtz-Eakin said, "We were looking for efficiencies in delivery a la Managed Medicaid."

Label: Neutral

Line: "President Obama achieved a third as much savings by eliminating unnecessary subsidies to insurances companies and getting waste and fraud out of the system in order to improve seniors' benefits -- saving them $600 a year on prescription drugs and providing them with access to preventive care.

Line: But the attack on McCain's accounting was part of the assault nonetheless.

Line: And in light of the current debate over Medicare proposals, it could complicate the political dialogue even further.

Line: WASHINGTON - Representative Paul D. Ryan's budget blueprint assumes the same amount of Medicare savings as President Obama's health care law, even though Mitt Romney and Mr. Ryan have said those cuts would be devastating to millions of older Americans on Medicare

Line: Even for a Congress known to battle over every little detail, reading the U.S. Constitution aloud sounded like a simple exercise.
Label: Informational

Line: Turned out it wasn't.
Label: Neutral

Line: Newly sworn members of the House reading aloud the country's founding document on Thursday didn't recite every verse and article of the document because Republicans decided that the obsolete parts can be skipped since they've been superseded by amendment.
Label: Neutral

Line: For instance, lawmakers did not read the 18th Amendment, which imposed prohibition on liquor in 1919.
Label: Neutral

Line: However, they did read the 21st Amendment, which repealed prohibition in 1933 and is still in force.
Label: Neutral

Line: Republicans also left out the part about counting slaves and Native Americans as three-fifths of a person.
Label: Neutral

Line: Portions of the U.S. Constitution are never deleted, just amended, as has been done 27 times in history.
Label: Neutral

Line: But all the original decisions remain in the Constitution, including in the copies authorized by Congress' Joint Committee on Printing and used in Thursday's reading.
Label: Neutral

Line: And that was the point of contention for Democratic lawmakers who complained that exempting parts of the document from the reading undermines the objective of the exercise.
Label: Lexical

Line: "This is very emotional for me," Rep. Jesse Jackson Jr., D-Ill., said on the floor before the reading began.
Label: Neutral

Line: "Given the struggle of African Americans, given the struggle of women, given the struggle of others to create a more perfect document, to hear that those elements of the Constitution that have been dedacted (sic) by amendment are no less serious, no less part of our ongoing struggle to improve the country and our desire to continue to improve the Constitution, many of us don't want that to be lost upon the reading of our sacred document," he said.
Label: Neutral

Line: Rep. Jay Inslee, D-Wash., commented that the original document has been changed through amendment, leaving the the reader to interpret the operative language.
Label: Neutral

Line: "I think it would be helpful to the members if you would explain to us how the determinations of what to read has been made or not made so that we all be on the same page as to congressional intent," he said to Rep. Bob Goodlatte, R-Va., who presided over the reading.
Label: Neutral

Line: Rep. Elijah Cummings, D-Md., questioned the reading of the "amended" Constitution.
Label: Neutral

Line: "To not read the full document, including all the text that was later amended, is to fail to acknowledge the struggle our nation has constantly fought, within and without, to 'keep' our Republic," he said in a written statement.
Label: Lexical

Line: "It is a failure to show Americans that while we seek a more perfect union, we do so from imperfect beginnings, through an imperfect history, with an imperfect government created by an imperfect document," he added.
Label: Informational

Line: "We fail to show the American people that imperfection is not to be feared and that our ability to constantly improve on what the Founders gave us is a blessing, not a reason for divisiveness."
Label: Lexical

Line: Other lawmakers decried the exercise altogether, saying the Constitution is a living document that shouldn't be followed to the letter.
Label: Neutral

Line: "They are reading it like a sacred text," Rep. Jerrold Nadler, D-N.Y., the former chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on the Constitution, Civil Rights and Civil Liberties, told The Washington Post.
Label: Informational

Line: Nadler derided what he called the "ritualistic reading" as "total nonsense" and "propaganda" intended to give Republicans claim to the document.
Label: Informational

Line: He argued that the Founders were not "demigods" and that the document's needs for amendments to abolish slavery and other injustices showed it was "highly imperfect."
Label: Neutral

Line: "You are not supposed to worship your Constitution," he told the newspaper.
Label: Informational

Line: "You are supposed to govern your government by it."
Label: Neutral

Line: But for all those who described the exercise as political waste -- including Vanity Fair magazine, which estimated it as costing more than $1 million -- supporters noted that it was an historic moment -- the first time the U.S. Constitution had been read on the U.S. House floor.
Label: Informational

Line: "I think that this is a very symbolic showing to the American people and reminder to the members of congress that we are a government of laws not of men and that this Constitution is the foundation for all of our laws," Goodlatte said.
Label: Neutral

Line: And backers said that it wouldn't hurt to try to live by the aspirations of the Founding Fathers.
Label: Neutral

Line: "I don't think the Constitution is propaganda.
Label: Neutral

Line: I think it's a valuable exercise and an important moment in this Congress for us to read the Constitution," said Rep. Steve Israel, D-N.Y.
Label: Neutral

Line: "But I do think that you can't just read it like a speech and then leave skid marks on it in your legislative record."
Label: Neutral

Line: Historian Alan Brinkley of Columbia University told Fox News the reading may be "a bit of theater," but it is "not insignificant given that many Republicans have decided -- implausibly, in my opinion -- that the Constitution is the vehicle that can reduce the size of government."
Label: Informational

Line: But Roger Pilon of the Cato Institute said Congress needs to re-read the Constitution to be reminded how out of control government has become.
Label: Neutral

Line: "Today the Congress regulates our lives and redistributes our wealth in ways that would shock the Founders," he said.
Label: Neutral

Line: "The Constitution, they wrote that to ensure limited government and they meant for most of us to live our lives free from government, in the private sector, planning and living our own lives, not as dependents on government goods and services."
Label: Neutral

Line: Pilon added that the Founders never intended for the Constitution to be viewed as fluid advice.
Label: Neutral

Line: "When liberals tell today that the Constitution is essentially a blank slate to be filled by transient majorities, nothing could be further from the truth.
Label: Neutral

Line: If that were so, it would never have been ratified in the first place," he said.
Label: Neutral

Line: As the Constitution was being read inside the lower chamber, Nadler and others gathered outside the Capitol to push for passage of the Equal Rights Amendment, a perennial effort to update the document with a statement on women.
Label: Neutral

Line: "John Boehner and his cronies are holding up the U.S. Constitution as a sacred, perfect document.
Label: Lexical

Line: But we know the Constitution is far from perfect because it does not guarantee women's equality," NOW President Terry O'Neill said in a statement.
Label: Neutral

Line: WASHINGTON - And on the second day of Republican rule, the House read the Constitution.
Label: Neutral

Line: Those wondering whether the reading would be dramatic found out on Thursday as volunteers gave voice to the seven articles and 27 amendments that make up the nation's governing document.
Label: Neutral

Line: Republicans have made strict adherence to the Constitution a key tenet of their effort to reduce the size of the federal government.
Label: Neutral

Line: The House GOP will reportedly make it a requirement that all new bills put forth in the legislative body include  a statement by the lawmaker who wrote it citing the constitutional authority to enact the proposed legislation.

Line: The Washington Post reported last week that reading the founding document in full appears to be a first in the chamber's 221-year history:
Label: Neutral

Label: Neutral

Line: Under axiomatic legal precedent, virtually all congressional action is presumed valid anyway, at least initially.

Line: Moreover, by taking their oaths of office, lawmakers swear to abide by the Constitution, and virtually all legislation is vetted for constitutional support on some level by government lawyers before it makes it to committee or to the floor of the House.

Line: According to Peter Keating at Vanity Fair, $1.1 million is the estimated cost of GOP plans to read the document on the House floor.

Line: When one chamber of Congress is in session but not working, we the people still have to pay for members' salaries and expenses, and for their police protection, and for keeping their lights and phones and coffee machines on.

Line: We always hear members of Congress talking about swearing an oath to represent their constituents, when in reality the only oath we take is to the Constitution,  explained newly-minted Speaker John Boehner to the Post.

Label: Neutral

Line: These new rules show that Republicans are serious about respecting the Constitution.
Label: Informational

Line: Also on Thursday, the House is to take up its first spending cut measure, a proposed 5 percent trim in the budgets of leadership, rank-and-file member and committee offices.

Line: Republicans have estimated that this will save $35 million over the next nine months.

Line: Setting the tone for the 112th Congress   in which every House bill must cite the constitutional source of its authority   members of the House of Representatives began to read the United States Constitution aloud from the chamber's floor on Thursday morning.
Label: Neutral

Line: Like the Constitutional Convention itself, things did not begin auspiciously.
Label: Neutral

Line: Before the reading began, Jay Inslee, Democrat of Washington, asked Republicans to illuminate exactly what part of the Constitution would be read, what parts would be deleted and who would decide how things would unfold.
Label: Neutral

Line: It was decided in advance that any portion of the Constitution that was superseded by amendments   including the amendments themselves   would not be read, preventing lawmakers from having to make references to slaves, referred to in Article 1, Section 2 as  three fifths of all other persons,  or to things like prohibition.
Label: Neutral

Line: These inquiries about parliamentary procedure were not well received, and for several minutes, before a word of the preamble could be uttered, Democrats and Republicans battled back and forth over the issue of language, perhaps presaging future partisan battles over the meaning, purpose and application of the document.
Label: Informational

Line: Once that was settled, just after 11 a.m., Representative John A. Boehner, the newly installed speaker of the House, read the preamble (that magical  We the people ), before yielding to the woman who handed him the gavel on Wednesday, Representative Nancy Pelosi, who picked up with Article 1, Section 1 ( All legislative powers herein granted shall be vested in a Congress of the United States, which shall consist of a Senate and House of Representatives ), followed by Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, and other House leaders.
Label: Neutral

Line: From there, members who wished to read were recognized from their seats, beginning with Representative Steve Rothman, Democrat of New Jersey.
Label: Neutral

Line: And so, sentence by sentence, in accents that reflect the myriad districts that did not even exist when the document came into being, by women and African Americans whose full rights were not recognized at that time, the constitutional language fluttered through the chamber.
Label: Neutral

Line: At one point, there was yelling in the chamber, and the sergeant-at-arms was called to remove a protester.
Label: Informational

Line: The reading of the document on the floor of the House, an act that is part of the new rules package, serves several purposes, said Representative Robert W. Goodlatte, Republican of Virginia, who came up with the idea for the live reading.
Label: Neutral

Line: Largely, it was meant to instruct members, who now must use it to underlie their bills, and to inform voters.
Label: Neutral

Line: Throughout the last year there has been a great debate about the expansion of the federal government, and lots of my constituents have said that Congress has gone beyond its powers granted in the Constitution,  said Mr. Goodlatte, a senior member of the House Judiciary Committee, which has jurisdiction over constitutional amendments.
Label: Neutral

Line: He added:  I think it is important that we send a message to people at home that the constitution is an important document.
Label: Neutral

Line: But it was also clearly meant as a nod to the Tea Party, a loosely organized political movement whose members cite the Constitution as the basis for much of their political theory concerning federal powers and the rights and responsibilities of Congress.
Label: Neutral

Line: To wit, the document reading happened on the same day that House Republicans began the contentious process of repealing the health care law, which they have long said lacks constitutional basis.
Label: Neutral

Line: The order of reading was ironed out at the last minute, with the goal of letting all who wished to read do so, but making sure there was party parity, Mr. Goodlatte said.
Label: Neutral

Line: We have spread the word to everyone, and there was a lot of interest,  he said.
Label: Neutral

Line: According to the Office of the Historian of the House of Representatives, the only two prior instances in which a full or partial text of the Constitution was inserted into the Congressional Record was in 1882, when Roswell Flower of New York  appended  a text of the Constitution   minus the amendments   into the record, and in 1915, when Thomas Reilly of Connecticut inserted the full text of the Constitution into the Congressional Record as an extension of his remarks.
Label: Neutral

Line: But the office could not find any examples of the full text of the Constitution actually being read out loud on the House Floor.
Label: Neutral

Line: NRA urges states to allow more armed officers in schools
Label: Neutral

Line: The National Rifle Association called Tuesday for state legislatures to allow more school personnel to carry weapons on school grounds once they've gone through extensive training, as part of a set of recommendations that capped a weeks-long review in the wake of the Newtown mass shooting.

Asa Hutchinson, who led the NRA's review, appeared to ease off slightly on the call for armed officers in every school -- he said it's "important" for every school to have at least one, but acknowledged these decisions are "locally made" based on unique budget circumstances.

Line: NRA School Safety Report Recommends Arming Teachers, Loosening Gun Laws
Label: Neutral

Line: WASHINGTON -- Former Rep. Asa Hutchinson (R-Ark.) on Tuesday released a 225-page report on school safety funded by the National Rifle Association.
Label: Neutral

Line: The report, commissioned in the wake of the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting, recommended properly trained armed employees to provide "an important layer of security in schools."
Label: Neutral

Line: The report was prepared by a 12-person task force, called the School Shield Program, led by Hutchinson.
Label: Neutral

Line: At Tuesday's press conference, he stated that its findings were independent of the nation's largest gun lobby.
Label: Neutral

Line: "Teachers should teach, but if there is personnel that has interest and is willing to go through 40 to 60 hours of [firearms] training, then schools should be willing to [arm them]," Hutchinson said.
Label: Neutral

Line: He added that the report found that "local school authorities are in the best position" to determine their own school security measures, "specifically whether an armed security guard is necessary and supported by the education and citizen community."
Label: Neutral

Line: The task force recommended that schools designate willing staff to be armed and trained, and it proposed a model training program, 40-60 hours per person, at what Hutchinson said would be a cost of about $800 to $1,000 per trained employee.
Label: Neutral

Line: Armed school personnel, called school resource officers, would also be required to undergo a "background investigation, testing, and [have] relevant experience."
Label: Neutral

Line: The committee didn't recommend any specific kind of firearm for school security, Hutchinson said, adding, "Everything from a sidearm, to a shotgun, to an AR-15" would work.
Label: Neutral

Line: The task force also suggested that states loosen current legal restrictions on who can carry a firearm on school property.
Label: Neutral

Line: Many states currently prohibit anyone but a law enforcement officer from possessing guns in a school.
Label: Neutral

Line: Other recommendations included creating threat assessment teams at schools, better coordinating state and federal funding for school security, and offering an online assessment tool, so that administrators can evaluate their schools' potential security gaps.

Line: It looks like President Trump is having a change of heart when it comes to his recent decision to lift the ban on importing elephant trophies from Africa.

Line: WASHINGTON   Two days after suddenly halting his own administration's decision to begin allowing hunters to import elephants killed in two African countries, President Donald Trump called such trophy hunting a  horror show  and said he's unlikely to change his mind and allow such imports.

Line: Big-game trophy decision will be announced next week but will be very hard pressed to change my mind that this horror show in any way helps conservation of Elephants or any other animal,  he posted to Twitter Sunday evening.
Label: Neutral

Line: In the face of widespread public backlash, Tump announced late Friday that he has suspended   at least for now   his administration's decision to reverse an Obama-era ban on the importation of elephant trophies from Zimbabwe and Zambia.

Line: Put big game trophy decision on hold until such time as I review all conservation facts,  he posted to Twitter.
Label: Neutral

Line: He adding that the issue has been  under study for years  but that he would provide an update after additional review.

Line: Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke said in a statement on Twitter that he and Trump  believe that conservation & healthy herds are critical.

Line: As HuffPost reported Wednesday, the administration optedto lift the 2014 ban after determining that sport hunting of elephants in those African countries would  enhance the survival of the species in the wild,  a spokesperson for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service said.

Line: It also recently rolled back protections for African lions, releasing new guidelines that allow big game hunters to bring back to the U.S. animal trophies from hunts in parts of Africa.
Label: Neutral

Line: The decision regarding elephants was made public not by the federal agency but via a celebratory news release early Tuesday from Safari Club International, a trophy hunting advocacy group that, along with the National Rifle Association, sued to block the 2014 ban.

Line: Greg Sheehan, principal deputy director of the FWS, broke the news to the hunting organization during the African Wildlife Consultative Forum in Tanzania, an agency spokesperson told HuffPost.

Line: We need immediate federal action to reverse these policies and protect these amazing animals.

Line: WASHINGTON   President Trump on Friday reversed the government's decision to start allowing hunters to import trophies of elephants that were killed in two African countries, pending a further review.
Label: Neutral

Line: His evening Twitter message reversed a decision by his own administration over Zimbabwe that was announced this week and promoted as recently as Friday afternoon by the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders.
Label: Neutral

Line: Put big game trophy decision on hold until such time as I review all conservation facts,  Mr. Trump tweeted.
Label: Neutral

Line: Under study for years. Will update soon with Secretary Zinke. Thank you!
Label: Neutral

Line: Ryan Zinke, the interior secretary, said in a statement later Friday night that the decision applied to two African countries, though it did not name them.
Label: Neutral

Line: President Trump and I have talked, and both believe that conservation and healthy herds are critical,  the statement said.
Label: Neutral

Line: As a result, in a manner compliant with all applicable laws, rules and regulations, the issuing of permits is being put on hold as the decision is being removed.
Label: Neutral

Line: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service had signaled its intention to end the 2014 ban, citing Zimbabwe's conservation efforts.
Label: Neutral

Line: On Thursday, the service announced on its website that it would begin issuing permits to allow the import of elephants hunted from 2016 to 2018, with two trophies allowed per import.
Label: Neutral

Line: Nearly two weeks ago, the department also waived the ban in a similar manner for Zambia.
Label: Neutral

Line: Zambia and Zimbabwe have had mixed success in recent years maintaining or increasing their elephant population, according to the Great Elephant Census, a project financed by Paul G. Allen, a founder of Microsoft.
Label: Neutral

Line: The project also found that the African elephant population shrunk nearly 30 percent from 2007 to 2014.

Line: It is unclear why Mr. Trump reversed the decision, but the announcement faced backlash from both conservatives and liberals.

Line: Laura Ingraham, a Fox News host, said Thursday on Twitter that she did not understand how the decision would not  INCREASE the gruesome poaching of elephants,  while the comedian Ellen DeGeneres started an online campaign, using the hashtag #BeKindToElephants, to raise funds for elephant conservation efforts.
Label: Lexical

Line: On social media, photos were being shared of Mr. Trump's two elder sons hunting on safari in Zimbabwe, including one photo that showed Donald Trump Jr. with a severed elephant tail in one hand and a knife in the other.

Line: The White House argued that the hunting would bring money to local communities and incentivize efforts to protect elephants.

Line: This review established that both Zambia and Zimbabwe had met new standards, strict international conservation standards that allowed Americans to resume hunting in those countries,  she told reporters during a news briefing.
Label: Neutral

Line: Under President Barack Obama, the practice had been banned because of a lack of data on conservation efforts in Zimbabwe.
Label: Neutral

Line: Safari Club International, a trophy-hunting organization that sued the Obama administration in 2014 in an effort to challenge the ban and was the first to report the policy change on Tuesday, lashed out against the news media and  anti-hunters  for swaying the Trump administration to lift the trophy ban.

Line: We will be more proactive and not back down.

Line: Ms. Sanders also confirmed Friday that a near-total ban on the commercial trade of African elephant ivory enforced during the Obama administration would remain in place.

Line: Attorney General Eric Holder said Wednesday that he understands why many black Americans distrust the police as he made a one-day swing through the St. Louis suburb of Ferguson, Mo., where a black teenager was fatally shot by a white police officer almost two weeks earlier.
Label: Neutral

Line: Holder made the comments during a meeting with about 50 community leaders at the Florissant campus of St. Louis Community College in which he heard about their own issues with law enforcement officials.
Label: Neutral

Line: Ferguson has endured more than a week of unrest since the August 9 death of 18-year-old Michael Brown, who was shot by Ferguson Police Officer Darren Wilson.
Label: Neutral

Line: The Obama administration intended the trip to underscore its commitment to civil rights in general and the Ferguson case in particular.
Label: Neutral

Line: "I understand that mistrust," Holder said.
Label: Neutral

Line: "I am the attorney general of the United States. But I am also a black man."
Label: Neutral

Line: The attorney general then described how he was stopped twice on the New Jersey Turnpike and accused of speeding.
Label: Neutral

Line: Police searched his car, going through the trunk and looking under the seats.
Label: Neutral

Line: "I remember how humiliating that was and how angry I was and the impact it had on me," Holder said.
Label: Neutral

Line: Holder also described how once, while living in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, he was running to catch a movie with his cousin when a squad car rolled up and flashed its lights at the pair.
Label: Neutral

Line: The officer yelled, "Where are you going? Hold it!" Holder recalled.
Label: Neutral

Line: His cousin "started mouthing off," and Holder urged him to be quiet.
Label: Neutral

Line: "We negotiate the whole thing, and we walk to our movie.
Label: Neutral

Line: At the time that he stopped me, I was a federal prosecutor. I wasn't a kid," he said.
Label: Neutral

Line: While in Ferguson, Holder met with federal officials investigating the case, as well as Brown's parents.
Label: Neutral

Line: He also met with Missouri Highway Patrol Capt. Ron Johnson, who has been in charge of security in Ferguson for nearly a week.
Label: Neutral

Line: The National Guard is also helping to keep the peace.
Label: Neutral

Line: On Wednesday night, a diminished number of protesters marched around a single block in Ferguson as a thunderstorm filled the sky with lighting and dumped rain.
Label: Neutral

Line: Police still stood guard, but many wore regular uniforms rather than riot gear.
Label: Neutral

Line: Johnson said there were six arrests Wednesday, compared to 47 the previous night.
Label: Neutral

Line: He called it "a very good night," and said Holder's visit had let people know their voices had been heard.
Label: Informational

Line: In nearby Clayton, a grand jury began hearing evidence to determine whether Wilson should be charged in Brown's death.
Label: Neutral

Line: FERGUSON, Mo. -- Attorney General Eric Holder said Wednesday that the  eyes of the nation and the world  are on this small suburb of St. Louis where an unarmed teenager was shot and killed by police earlier this month.
Label: Neutral

Line: The issues raised by Michael Brown's death, Holder said, have simmered  beneath the surface in more communities than just Ferguson.

Line: FERGUSON, Mo.   Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. arrived in St. Louis on Wednesday, meeting with community leaders and federal investigators even as local law enforcement officials said they were hopeful that they had turned a corner in calming the restive community of Ferguson after 12 days of protests and unrest.
Label: Lexical

Line: Mr. Holder's first stop was at a community college, where he met with people who told him about their own personal experiences with the local police, some of which they said helped fuel the rage that was ultimately ignited by the shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer on Aug. 9.
Label: Lexical

Line: There were more protests planned throughout the day and into the evening, but Capt. Ronald S. Johnson of the Missouri State Highway Patrol said he believed they had reached  a turning point.
Label: Neutral

Line: Captain Johnson, whose agency is overseeing security here, said there were only sporadic problems on Tuesday night, and none of the wide-scale looting and confrontations that had erupted on other nights.
Label: Neutral

Line: Still, the police did make 47 arrests overnight.
Label: Neutral

Line: As the tension on the street seemed to ease, the focus turned to the investigation into the shooting death of Michael Brown.
Label: Neutral

Line: A grand jury has been convened and was scheduled to meet Wednesday to begin hearing evidence, said Edward Magee, a spokesman for Robert P. McCulloch, the prosecuting attorney for St. Louis County.
Label: Neutral

Line: Protesters gathered outside Mr. McCulloch's office on Wednesday, calling for him to step aside.
Label: Neutral

Line: They argued that he could not be impartial because his father, a police officer, was shot and killed by a black man while on duty when Mr. McCulloch was a child.
Label: Neutral

Line: Mr. McCulloch, speaking to a local radio station, categorically rejected that notion.
Label: Neutral

Line: I know the pain the Brown family is going through right now,  he said.
Label: Neutral

Line: He said he has only one interest: conducting a fair and thorough investigation.
Label: Neutral

Line: But he acknowledged that Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri has the power to appoint a new prosecutor.
Label: Neutral

Line: Anyone who wants me off the case needs to call up the governor and express their opinion to him,  Mr. McCulloch told KTRS radio.
Label: Neutral

Line: By failing to act, Mr. McCulloch said, the governor  undermines everything except the cover he has pulled over his head.
Label: Neutral

Line: He told him to  man up  and make a decision so that the case will not be further delayed.
Label: Neutral

Line: Mr. Magee cautioned that it could take weeks for the grand jury to consider all of the evidence.
Label: Neutral

Line: He said that Officer Darren Wilson, who shot Mr. Brown, had been interviewed by police investigators and would be given the opportunity to testify.
Label: Neutral

Line: The Justice Department, meanwhile, has started a separate inquiry.
Label: Neutral

Line: More than 40 F.B.I. agents have been dispatched to Ferguson, and Mr. Holder said they are not only investigating the shooting but also looking for any broad patterns of civil rights violations.
Label: Neutral

Line: In an open letter to the people of Ferguson, Mr. Holder said he understood the desire of residents for an  independent  inquiry.
Label: Neutral

Line: This is my pledge to the people of Ferguson: Our investigation into this matter will be full, it will be fair, and it will be independent,  Mr. Holder wrote in The St. Louis Post-Dispatch.
Label: Neutral

Line: And beyond the investigation itself, we will work with the police, civil rights leaders, and members of the public to ensure that this tragedy can give rise to new understanding   and robust action   aimed at bridging persistent gaps between law enforcement officials and the communities we serve.
Label: Neutral

Line: The frustrations in the community have been fueled in part by the slow pace with which the authorities have released information.
Label: Neutral

Line: In a sign of just how deep the distrust runs, there were three separate autopsies performed on Mr. Brown's body: one by the county medical examiner, one by a private pathologist hired by the family, and one by federal authorities.
Label: Neutral

Line: In addition to the many lingering questions about the shooting, the local authorities have also come under criticism for how they have handled the protests.
Label: Neutral

Line: Norm Stamper, the former Seattle police chief who was in charge during the protests that rocked that city in 1999, said that the wrong tone was set from the first day in Ferguson.
Label: Informational

Line: The basic perspective that I have over this whole thing, dating back to the shooting incident itself, what we had were largely peaceful vigils and protests that were met with police tactics that were highly aggressive and militaristic,  he said.
Label: Informational

Line: That response ignited what we have seen all week.
Label: Neutral

Line: He reserved his harshest criticism for the use of tear gas by the police   a mistake he said he made in Seattle and one he regrets to this day.
Label: Informational

Line: Since the first day of protests in Ferguson, the authorities shifted their response almost daily, adding to the sense that the situation was out of control.
Label: Informational

Line: On one day, protesters were told to gather in one place. Another day, they were told to keep moving.
Label: Neutral

Line: Then a curfew was imposed. The next night, there was no curfew.
Label: Neutral

Line: The local police were in control; then another unit took over.
Label: Neutral

Line: The National Guard was finally brought in to try to temper the unrest, but its role was not exactly clear.
Label: Neutral

Line: You get governors and police chiefs and everyone gnashing their teeth,  Mr. Stamper said.
Label: Neutral

Line: Even the protesters are commenting on that: what are they doing?
Label: Informational

Line: On Tuesday night, however, it seemed that some of that energy had gone from the streets.
Label: Neutral

Line: And the police also seemed more restrained, refraining from using tear gas.
Label: Neutral

Line: The evening began in a familiar fashion: Demonstrators marched along the street and chanted  Hands up! Don't shoot!  and other slogans that have become common here since Mr. Brown's death.
Label: Neutral

Line: The authorities made at least 47 arrests after demonstrators tossed bottles toward police officers, some of whom used pepper spray to subdue some protesters.
Label: Neutral

Line: In some instances, teams of officers abruptly entered the crowd, detained a single person whom they had apparently focused on, and returned to West Florissant Avenue, where many of the recent confrontations have occurred.
Label: Neutral

Line: Although law enforcement officers in riot gear eyed the protesters while a police helicopter occasionally circled the city, there were no signs of trouble for long stretches of the evening.
Label: Neutral

Line: When a demonstration ended shortly before midnight, many of the demonstrators prayed.

Line: Now that's what I call a good protest,  Jonathan Smith, 45, said.

Line: NJ Gov Chris Christie to Throw His Hat in the Ring for White House Run

Label: Neutral

Line: Chris Christie Announces He's Running For President In 2016
Label: Neutral

Line: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie (R) announced he's running for president in 2016.

Line: "Both parties have failed our country... both parties have led us to believe that America, a country that was built on compromise -- that compromise is somehow a dirty word," Christie said.

Line: LIVINGSTON, N.J.   Gov. Chris Christie declared an uphill candidacy for president on Tuesday with New Jersey-style swagger, unconcealed disgust for Washington and a high regard for his own candor, vowing that  there is one thing you will know for sure: I say what I mean and I mean what I say.
Label: Informational

Line: Relying on his biggest, and perhaps his last, remaining advantage in a field of better-financed and better-liked rivals   his personality   Mr. Christie portrayed himself as the only candidate in the Republican field who is forthright and forceful enough to run the country.
Label: Informational

Line: We need strength and decision-making and authority back in the Oval Office,  he said.
Label: Neutral

Line: Pacing the stage without a prepared text and raising his voice to a shout at times, he vowed to campaign and govern as a colorful teller of difficult truths, even if  it makes you cringe every once in a while.
Label: Informational

Line: I am not running for president of the United States as surrogate for being elected prom king of America,  Mr. Christie said inside the gymnasium at the high school where he was president of his class all three years.
Label: Informational

Line: I am not going to be the most popular guy who looks into your eye every day and says what you want to hear,  he continued.
Label: Neutral

Line: Trying to claw his way back to the top of the Republican field, Mr. Christie took a pointed swipe at his rivals who are in the United States Senate, like Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz, who have never run a state government.
Label: Lexical

Line: Unlike some people who offer themselves for president in 2016, you won't have to wonder whether I can do it or not,  he said, invoking the  economic calamity  he said he inherited in 2010 and the  unprecedented natural disaster,  Hurricane Sandy, that he weathered as governor.
Label: Neutral

Line: But he reserved his deepest disdain for Congress and for the president's stewardship of foreign affairs, and extended that critique to President Obama's former secretary of state.
Label: Neutral

Line: After seven years of a weak and feckless foreign policy run by Barack Obama, we better not turn it over to his second mate, Hillary Clinton,  Mr. Christie said.
Label: Neutral

Line: Still, he blamed both parties for dysfunction and gridlock in Washington.
Label: Neutral

Line: If Washington and Adams and Jefferson believed that compromise was a dirty word, we'd still be under the crown of England,  he said.
Label: Neutral

Line: Mr. Christie, whose dazzling rise as a national Republican in his first term was matched only by his spectacular loss of stature at home in his second, entered the presidential race bearing little resemblance to the candidate he once expected to be.
Label: Lexical

Line: The economic recovery he promised has turned into a cascade of ugly credit downgrades and anemic job growth.
Label: Informational

Line: The state pension system he vowed to fix has descended into a morass of missed payments and lawsuits.
Label: Informational

Line: The administration he pledged would be a paragon of ethics has instead conspired to mire an entire town in traffic and the governor's office in scandal.
Label: Informational

Line: Three and a half years ago, Mr. Christie seemed such an antidote to all that ailed the Republican brand that senior figures in the party pleaded with him to run for president as a substitute for the eventual nominee, Mitt Romney.
Label: Neutral

Line: But now, a staggering 55 percent of Republican primary voters say that they cannot envision voting for Mr. Christie, according to an NBC-Wall Street Journal Poll.
Label: Neutral

Line: The only candidate less palatable: Donald J. Trump, the bombastic developer turned reality television star.
Label: Neutral

Line: With two pillars of his presidential run   his record and his judgment   looking wobbly, Mr. Christie must now build a campaign around his most raw and prodigious asset: his personality, a magnetic mix of quick-witted charm, insult-trading banter, vulnerability, empathy and effrontery.
Label: Neutral

Line: It was on vivid display Tuesday before hundreds of supporters, including many of Mr. Christie's oldest friends and most loyal aides.
Label: Neutral

Line: He joked about the need for a new and refined tax code that would finally put his father, a certified public account standing nearby, out of business.
Label: Neutral

Line: He described the decision to enter politics as a  coin toss  between him and his wife, Mary Pat, herself a nimble political mind.
Label: Neutral

Line: And he put an unusual twist on the dilemma facing the financially stretched Social Security system.
Label: Neutral

Line: The lying and stealing has already happened, the horse is out of the barn, we need to get it back in, and the only way to do it is by force,  he said.
Label: Neutral

Line: Mr. Christie, 52, honed his political technique, and developed a YouTube following, during a remarkable run of 137 town-hall-style meetings across New Jersey.
Label: Lexical

Line: Not surprisingly, he plans to put the town hall meeting at the center of his candidacy   and to put his hopes in a state, New Hampshire, that is famed for its own town hall meetings.
Label: Neutral

Line: He is forgoing the customary tour of early-voting states that usually follows a formal announcement, aides said.
Label: Neutral

Line: Instead, Mr. Christie will plant himself in New Hampshire for a week, holding one town hall after another.
Label: Neutral

Line: Such single-mindedness belies the serious and stubborn vulnerabilities of his campaign.
Label: Informational

Line: As a centrist candidate from the Northeast, he would have a difficult path to the Republican presidential nomination under the best circumstances.
Label: Neutral

Line: And circumstances are anything but optimal for him: He faces a wide field of candidates, including several who are better financed and beloved by mainstream donors (Jeb Bush), hold greater appeal to conservative voters who dominate the primary process (Scott Walker), are agile public speakers with persuasive biographies (Mr. Rubio), or are better liked by Republican voters (all of the above).
Label: Neutral

Line: At his announcement, Mr. Christie sought political rebirth, as he has before, by relying on his powers as a narrator, and mythologizer, of his own story.
Label: Neutral

Line: Running for president is a new and bigger stage, though, and both Mr. Christie's stagecraft and his oratory showed room for improvement.
Label: Neutral

Line: The first speaker who preceded him to the stage had no microphone, causing a delay; later on, she was booed when she disclosed that she was a Democrat.
Label: Neutral

Line: Without a text, Mr. Christie frequently descended into clichs.
Label: Informational

Line: The truth will set us free,  he said at one point.
Label: Neutral

Line: One person can make a difference,  he said at another.
Label: Neutral

Line: But he also spoke with emotional power, as when he recalled his father's early job in an ice cream factory in Newark.
Label: Neutral

Line: Think about how amazing this country is,  Mr. Christie said.
Label: Neutral

Line: That one generation removed from that guy who was working on the floor of the Breyers ice cream plant, his son is the two-term governor of the state that he was born and raised in.
Label: Neutral

Line: The question for Mr. Christie, after a bruising year of watching his story rewritten by others, may be whether Republican voters, who can choose from among a long and intriguing list of fresher faces, will give him a fighting chance to sell himself anew.
Label: Neutral

Line: Arizona Sheriff Joe Arpaio, known for his tough and controversial stances on illegal immigration, endorsed three term Texas Governor Rick Perry for the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday morning during a campaign swing with Mr. Perry through New Hampshire.

Line: The self-titled America's Toughest Sheriff, who famously re-instituted chain gangs in 1995 and has also been a major supporter of his state's controversial SB1070 immigration law, said that Perry has done more to combat illegal immigration along the U.S. border then any of the other candidates.

Line: With a little more than a month to go before the New Hampshire primary, the Texas governor is trying to shore up his credentials on immigration: On Tuesday he won an endorsement from one of the nation's most outspoken and controversial public officials on that issue: Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, Ariz., who unabashedly calls himself the  toughest sheriff  in the country.

Line: Republican National Committee Chairman Michael Steele will speak with RNC members Monday evening in which he is expected to announce a decision about whether to make another run for the party chairmanship.

Line: The White House asked former President Bill Clinton to talk to Rep. Line: Colorado's top cop defends pot law after challenges from neighboring states
Label: Neutral

Line: Denver (AP)   Colorado's top law enforcement official promises to vigorously defend the state's historic law legalizing marijuana after Nebraska and Oklahoma asked the U.S. Supreme Court to declare it unconstitutional, saying the drug is freely flowing into neighboring states.
Label: Neutral

Line: The two states filed a lawsuit seeking a court order to prevent Colorado from enforcing the measure known as Amendment 64, which was approved by voters in 2012 and allows recreational marijuana for adults over 21.
Label: Neutral

Line: The complaint says the measure runs afoul of federal law and therefore violates the Constitution's supremacy clause, which says federal laws trump state laws.
Label: Neutral

Line: Colorado Attorney General John Suthers said the lawsuit was without merit.
Label: Neutral

Line: "Because neighboring states have expressed concern about Colorado-grown marijuana coming into their states, we are not entirely surprised by this action," he said.
Label: Neutral

Line: "However, it appears the plaintiffs' primary grievance stems from non-enforcement of federal laws regarding marijuana, as opposed to choices made by the voters of Colorado."
Label: Neutral

Line: The lawsuit says Colorado marijuana flows into neighboring states undermining their efforts to enforce their anti-marijuana laws.
Label: Neutral

Line: "This contraband has been heavily trafficked into our state," Nebraska Attorney General Jon Bruning said at a news conference in Lincoln.
Label: Neutral

Line: "While Colorado reaps millions from the sale of pot, Nebraska taxpayers have to bear the cost."
Label: Informational

Line: Colorado has raised more than $60 million in taxes, licenses and fees from medical and recreational marijuana, which has been sold in stores since January.
Label: Neutral

Line: The lawsuit says the sales have strained Nebraska and Oklahoma's finances and legal systems.
Label: Neutral

Line: Police are spending more time and money making arrests, housing inmates, impounding vehicles, seizing drugs and handling other problems related to Colorado pot.
Label: Neutral

Line: Bruning, a Republican, blamed U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder for failing to enforce the federal law's ban on drugs in Colorado.

Line: It laid out eight federal law enforcement priorities that states need to protect if they want to authorize "marijuana-related conduct."

Line: Nebraska, Oklahoma File Federal Suit Against Colorado Over Marijuana Legalization
Label: Neutral

Line: The states of Nebraska and Oklahoma filed a federal lawsuit in the U.S. Supreme Court Thursday, claiming that Colorado's legalization of recreational marijuana is unconstitutional under federal law.
Label: Neutral

Line: "Federal law undisputedly prohibits the production and sale of marijuana," Nebraska Attorney General Jon Bruning said Thursday in a statement.
Label: Neutral

Line: "Colorado has undermined the United States Constitution, and I hope the U.S. Supreme Court will uphold our constitutional principles."
Label: Informational

Line: But Colorado Attorney General John Suthers isn't backing down.
Label: Neutral

Line: In a statement, he said he intends to defend the state's marijuana laws.
Label: Neutral

Line: Because neighboring states have expressed concern about Colorado-grown marijuana coming into their states, we are not entirely surprised by this action," Suthers said.
Label: Neutral

Line: "However, it appears the plaintiffs' primary grievance stems from non-enforcement of federal laws regarding marijuana, as opposed to choices made by the voters of Colorado.

Line: We believe this suit is without merit and we will vigorously defend against it in the U.S. Supreme Court.

Line: DENVER   Two heartland states filed the first major court challenge to marijuana legalization on Thursday, saying that Colorado's growing array of state-regulated recreational marijuana shops was piping marijuana into neighboring states and should be shut down.

Line: President Trump said Thursday he is  very close  to naming a new FBI director to replace James Comey, and his leading contender is former Democratic Sen. Joe Lieberman.
Label: Neutral

Line: Lieberman, 75, who served in the Senate from 1989-2013, first as a Democrat and then as an independent, met with Trump at the White House on Wednesday afternoon to discuss leading the law enforcement agency.
Label: Neutral

Line: A late and somewhat unlikely addition to Trump's short list, Lieberman is nonetheless the sudden frontrunner.
Label: Neutral

Line: When asked point-blank by a reporter in the Oval Office Thursday if Lieberman was the leading contender, Trump replied, "Yes."
Label: Neutral

Line: Trump also met Wednesday with current acting FBI Director Andrew McCabe, former Oklahoma Gov. Frank Keating and FBI official Richard McFeely.
Label: Neutral

Line: Lieberman's law enforcement experience stems from his two-term tenure as Connecticut's attorney general, spanning from 1983 until his resignation in 1989 when he was elected to the U.S. Senate.
Label: Neutral

Line: Lieberman, who ran as vice president on Al Gore's 2000 ticket, became an independent after losing the Democratic primary in 2006.
Label: Neutral

Label: Neutral

Label: Neutral

Label: Neutral

Label: Neutral

Line: WASHINGTON   President Donald Trump is  very close  to selecting an interim candidate to replace former FBI Director James Comey, he told White House reporters on Thursday.

Line: In a head-to-head battle of proxies, Vice President Biden wasted no time Thursday trying to do what many Democrats felt President Obama failed to against Mitt Romney, going on offense with an often disdainful attack on Paul Ryan -- who stood his ground against a barrage of Biden grins, guffaws, snickers and interruptions.

Line: DANVILLE, Ky.  - Joe Biden did everything President Barack Obama did not last week, and a good bit more.

Line: Romney told a local Denver TV station earlier on Wednesday that he opposes both same-sex marriage and civil unions.
Label: Neutral

Line: "Well, when these issues were raised in my state of Massachusetts, I indicated my view, which is I do not favor marriage between people of the same gender, and I do not favor civil unions if they are identical to marriage other than by name," Romney told Denver Fox affiliate KDVR-TV.
Label: Neutral

Line: Like many conservative Republicans, Mitt Romney is opposed not only to same-sex marriage, but also to the civil unions that many states have adopted as an alternative to full marital rights for gay couples.
Label: Neutral

Line: Now that President Obama, long a supporter of civil unions, has publicly embraced same-sex marriage, the question of precisely what legal status and protections should be granted to gay couples is emerging as an issue of the starkest possible contrast between the two presidential candidates.
Label: Neutral

Line: In short, both Mr. Romney and Mr. Obama have adopted the favored position of their ideological base on a subject that profoundly animates both of those camps.
Label: Neutral

Line: On Wednesday, in anticipation of Mr. Obama's announcement, Mr. Romney laid out his belief that marriage   and anything resembling it   should be restricted to heterosexual couples, even as he acknowledged that it was  a very tender and sensitive topic.
Label: Neutral

Line: In doing so, he left open many questions about what his vision of legally recognizable gay unions would encompass, and what it would exclude.

Line: My view is the same as it's been from the beginning,  Mr. Romney told a CBS affiliate in Denver.
Label: Neutral

Line: I don't favor civil unions if it's identical to marriage, and I don't favor marriage between people of the same gender.

Line: Asked why he opposed civil unions, in particular, he explained that in many cases they represent marriage by a different name for gay couples.

Line: If a civil union is identical to marriage other than with the name, why, I don't support that,  he said Wednesday.

Line: Those states offer an array of different rights to same-sex couples, among them the ability to pool resources for tax purposes, place a spouse on an employee health care plan and inherit property after a death.

Line: The NAACP adopted a resolution Tuesday condemning "racist elements" in the Tea Party movement and calling on the movement's leaders to repudiate bigotry, despite claims from Tea Partiers that the measure is just a political ploy.
Label: Neutral

Line: The nation's leading civil rights group took up the language at its annual convention in Kansas City, Mo.
Label: Neutral

Line: The resolution initially said the NAACP would "repudiate the racism of the Tea Parties" and stand against the movement's attempt to "push our country back to the pre-civil rights era," though the wording was amended to downplay criticism of all Tea Partiers while asking them to repudiate bigots in their own ranks.
Label: Informational

Line: "We take no issue with the Tea Party movement.
Label: Neutral

Line: We believe in freedom of assembly and people raising their voices in a democracy," the NAACP President Benjamin Todd Jealous said in a written statement announcing the unanimous vote.
Label: Neutral

Line: "What we take issue with is the Tea Party's continued tolerance for bigotry and bigoted statements.
Label: Informational

Line: "The time has come for them to accept the responsibility that comes with influence and make clear there is no place for racism and anti-Semitism, homophobia and other forms of bigotry in their movement."
Label: Neutral

Line: NAACP leaders have referenced an incident in March when Tea Party protesters allegedly hurled racial epithets at black lawmakers on Capitol Hill ahead of a health care vote.
Label: Neutral

Line: But Tea Party members have challenged claims that their activists accosted black lawmakers in March and no visual evidence has been produced depicting a racist attack.
Label: Informational

Line: Dallas Tea Party founder Phillip Dennis said "there was no proof" of racist behavior at the event and that the movement welcomes minority members.
Label: Neutral

Line: "We don't care about the pigment of one's skin," he said.
Label: Neutral

Line: Dennis accused the NAACP of playing the "race card" and called the organization "irrelevant."
Label: Neutral

Label: Neutral

Line: The group has drafted a resolution of its own condemning the civil rights group for reducing itself to a "bigoted" and "partisan attack dog organization."
Label: Informational

Line: Debate was mostly closed to the public, but the final version "calls on the tea party and all people of good will to repudiate the racist element and activities within the tea party," said Hilary Shelton, director of the NAACP's Washington bureau.
Label: Neutral

Line: The final wording won't be released until the NAACP's national board of directors approves the resolution during its meeting in October.
Label: Neutral

Line: But the original called for the NAACP to "educate its membership and the community that this movement is not just about higher taxes and limited government."

Line: It said something could evolve "and become more dangerous for that small percentage of people that really think our country has been taken away from them."

Line: WASHINGTON   A young Republican congressional aide resigned Monday after her Facebook post berating President Obama's daughters for their attitude and outfits during the annual White House turkey pardon became a sensation on the Internet.
Label: Lexical

Label: Informational

Line: GOP Rep. Paul Ryan is heading to Georgetown University for a speech Thursday morning, but not before an old-fashioned, Catholic school knuckle-rapping.

Line: President Trump's immigration compromise package to end the partial government shutdown drew sharp reactions from Democratic and Republican lawmakers alike.

Line: WASHINGTON   President Donald Trump's offer to Democrats over the weekend seeking to trade temporary protections for some immigrants in exchange for funding for a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border received positive coverage from some outlets, including being called a  compromise  and a move by Trump  toward the center.
Label: Neutral

Line: But the latest details in the proposal, which Senate Republicans unveiled Monday in a bill they plan to vote on this week, make the offer appear less of a compromise and more of a wish list for immigration hard-liners like White House adviser Stephen Miller.
Label: Informational

Line: Trump is offering a three-year extension for the Obama-era Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, which protects from deportation hundreds of thousands of immigrants brought to the U.S. as kids.
Label: Neutral

Line: The offer would also give a three-year extension to 300,000 people from El Salvador, Haiti, Nicaragua and Honduras who are living in the U.S. under the temporary protected status program.
Label: Neutral

Line: Democrats rejected the offer before Trump even announced it on Saturday, however, maintaining that it didn't go nearly far enough and that the president ought to reopen the government before any negotiations over the border proceed.
Label: Neutral

Line: But the GOP bill incorporating his offer would also gut existing asylum laws for children and trafficking victims from Central America, ban asylum for minors who present themselves at ports of entry, gut the concept of temporary protected status for future cases and expand immigration detention   all measures making it more likely to be dead on arrival in the Senate.
Label: Lexical

Line: Given the poison pills stuffed into a proposal that was supposed to entice Democrats we can now say the Trump 'offer' isn't about getting to a deal but about shifting blame.
Label: Neutral

Line: So obvious. So predictable. So pathetic,  Frank Sharry, the executive director of the immigration advocacy group America's Voice, tweeted on Tuesday.
Label: Informational

Line: The bill would ban asylum for Central American minors, including those who arrive at the border with their parents, unless the minors apply for asylum in their home country.
Label: Neutral

Line: It would also cap the number of Central American minors who are allowed to apply for asylum each year at 50,000 and limit the number of asylum applications that could be granted per year to 15,000.
Label: Neutral

Line: The administration has for months tried to reduce the number of people seeking asylum in the U.S. as part of a broader effort to stem the flow of Central American migrants crossing the border from Mexico.
Label: Neutral

Line: Trump's administrative attempts to curtail the asylum process have faced legal challenges in two federal courts, however, prompting this week's legislative fix.
Label: Neutral

Line: This bill includes the most extreme changes on asylum that I've ever seen,  Kerri Talbot, the director of federal advocacy at the group Immigration Hub, said on a press call on Tuesday.
Label: Neutral

Line: Under the GOP bill, minors who apply for asylum would face much stiffer consequences for filing an application found to be frivolous   including permanent ineligibility for future protections.
Label: Neutral

Line: The bill's changes to asylum law alarmed immigration activists online, as well some on the right, including attorney and conservative writer Gabriel Malor.
Label: Lexical

Line: Trump's efforts to win over Democratic support on the bill   which will require at least 60 votes to pass in the Senate   hit even more trouble on Tuesday after the Supreme Court once again did not act on the administration's effort to end DACA.
Label: Neutral

Line: The move essentially left protections for Dreamers in place for at least the next several months   giving Democrats less incentive to agree to Trump's offer of protections to DACA recipients.
Label: Neutral

Line: WASHINGTON   President Trump, facing a growing public backlash over the partial government shutdown, shifted course on Saturday and offered Democrats a deal: temporary protections for roughly 700,000 young undocumented immigrants in exchange for $5.7 billion in funding for a wall along the southern border.
Label: Neutral

Line: But the proposal, which Mr. Trump unveiled in a 13-minute address from the White House, appeared dead on arrival in the Capitol.
Label: Neutral

Line: Speaker Nancy Pelosi rejected it even before Mr. Trump spoke, and Senator Chuck Schumer, the Democratic leader, denounced the offer as  not a compromise but more hostage taking.

Line: With the shutdown entering its fifth week and polls showing a majority of the public blaming Mr. Trump, the president's advisers have been searching for an exit strategy.
Label: Neutral

Label: Neutral

Line: President Obama was heading to Detroit Monday afternoon to continue campaigning for tax hikes on top earners -- a day after a face-to-face meeting with House Speaker John Boehner that offered slight hope the two could be making progress toward a deal.
Label: Neutral

Line: The president and the speaker met Sunday afternoon at the White House for the first time in weeks.
Label: Neutral

Line: It came after Boehner publicly chided Obama on Friday for the lack of progress to date, accusing the president of having "wasted another week."
Label: Lexical

Line: Both sides were tightlipped about the surprise Sunday afternoon meeting.
Label: Neutral

Line: But instead of emerging from the talks complaining about each other, as was the case following phone calls last week, each side released an identical statement.
Label: Neutral

Line: "This afternoon, the President and Speaker Boehner met at the White House to discuss efforts to resolve the fiscal cliff.
Label: Neutral

Line: We're not reading out details of the conversation, but the lines of communication remain open," the statement released by each office said.
Label: Neutral

Line: Lawmakers and the White House have three weeks to reach a deal, before a potentially crippling set of tax hikes and spending cuts takes effect.
Label: Neutral

Line: Boehner last week put a counter-proposal on the table that included $800 billion in revenue increases over the next decade.

Line: While Boehner cast that as a significant concession, Obama said it didn't go far enough because it didn't include an increase in tax rates for the top 2 percent.

Line: Boehner, though, is facing some pressure from Republicans to give a little bit more.
Label: Neutral

Line: The speaker is effectively caught between two competing wings of the Republican Party.
Label: Neutral

Line: Some say Congress should not raise any taxes, and were disappointed he went so far as to put any revenue on the table.
Label: Neutral

Line: However, a growing number of Republicans are suggesting the party should give Obama what he wants on tax rates -- and focus instead on winning entitlement cuts once that is cleared away.

Line: Sen. Bob Corker, R-Tenn., became the latest Republican to open the door to tax rate hikes during an interview on "Fox News Sunday."
Label: Neutral

Line: "There is a growing group of folks that are looking at this and realizing that we don't have a lot of cards as it relates to the tax issue, before year-end.

Line: I mean, we have one house, that's it," Corker said.
Label: Neutral

Line: Corker suggested that Republicans instead focus on extracting entitlement cuts as part of the debt-ceiling negotiations.
Label: Neutral

Line: "Republicans know that they have the debt ceiling that's coming up right around the corner, and the leverage is going to shift, as soon as we get beyond this issue," Corker said on "Fox News Sunday."
Label: Neutral

Line: "The leverage is going to shift to our side, where hopefully we'll do the same thing we did last time."
Label: Neutral

Line: Corker said that if the president wants to raise the debt limit by $2 trillion, Republicans should press for $2 trillion in spending cuts.
Label: Neutral

Line: That prospect is sure to infuriate the White House.
Label: Neutral

Line: After the bruising debt-ceiling fight from 2011, Obama recently warned that he will not "play that game" again.
Label: Neutral

Line: "We've got to break that habit before it starts," the president said.
Label: Neutral

Line: The president argues that fights over the debt ceiling merely shake global confidence in the country's ability to pay its bills, and as part of talks over the looming fiscal crisis has called for a de facto permanent increase in the debt limit.

Line: It's now time to govern. The election is over," he said on NBC's "Meet the Press."

Line: WASHINGTON -- President Barack Obama and House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) met for nearly an hour on Thursday evening in their latest attempt to break the impasse on impending tax hikes and spending cuts.
Label: Neutral

Line: True to form, neither said much of anything about what was discussed.
Label: Neutral

Line: Shortly after the meeting ended, both camps put out identical, banal statements.
Label: Neutral

Label: Neutral

Label: Neutral

Label: Neutral

Line: The continued dialogue provides some rays of hope to a negotiating process that, in recent days, has shown very little progress.

Line: WASHINGTON   The Obama administration tried Saturday to marshal new evidence in defense of its collection of private Internet and telephone data, arguing that a secret program called Prism is simply an  internal government computer system  designed to sort through court-supervised collection of data, and that Congress has been briefed 13 times on the programs since 2009.

Line: WASHINGTON   Legally married same-sex couples will now be allowed to file federal joint tax returns, the IRS and Treasury Department announced Thursday.

Label: Neutral

Line: Thursday's ruling by Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew provides a uniform policy for the IRS; the state of celebration -- where the wedding took place -- now trumps the state of residency when it comes to federal tax status for same-sex married couples.

Line: Today's ruling provides certainty and clear, coherent tax filing guidance for all legally married same-sex couples nationwide.

Line: WASHINGTON   All same-sex couples who are legally married will be recognized as such for federal tax purposes, even if the state where they live does not recognize their union, the Treasury Department and the Internal Revenue Service said Thursday.
Label: Neutral

Label: Neutral

Line: The Treasury Department answered some of those questions on Thursday.
Label: Neutral

Line: As of the 2013 tax year, same-sex spouses who are legally married will not be able to file federal tax returns as if either were single.
Label: Neutral

Line: Instead, they must file together as  married filing jointly  or individually as  married filing separately.
Label: Neutral

Line: Their address or the location of their wedding does not matter, as long as the marriage is legal: a same-sex couple who marry in Albany, N.Y., and move to Alabama are treated the same as a same-sex couple who marry and live in Massachusetts.

Line: Today's ruling provides certainty and clear, coherent tax-filing guidance for all legally married same-sex couples nationwide,  Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew said.

Line: This ruling also assures legally married same-sex couples that they can move freely throughout the country knowing that their federal filing status will not change.

Line: These families finally have access to crucial tax benefits and protections previously denied to them under the discriminatory Defense of Marriage Act.

Line: But the Treasury decision could have ramifications for many gay couples' tax liabilities, said Roberton Williams of the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center in Washington.

Line: These state taxing authorities will have to figure out how to deal with a same-sex married couple who file a joint income tax return for federal tax purposes.  He added,
Label: Neutral

Line: The House Ethics Committee announced in November that Grimm was under investigation for possible campaign finance violations.

Line: Grimm made headlines in January after confronting a New York City cable news station reporter who tried to question him about a long-running FBI investigation into campaign finance on a balcony in the Capitol.
Label: Neutral

Line: After reporter Michael Scotto finished his report, Grimm stormed back, leaned into him and said, "Let me be clear to you.

Line: If you ever do that to me again, I'll throw you off this (expletive) balcony."

Line: Scotto, who was asking about fundraising during Grimm's first campaign, protested, saying he was asking "a valid question."

Line: During that race, Grimm has acknowledged receiving $250,000 to $300,000 in contributions from followers of an Israeli rabbi, Yoshiyahu Yosef Pinto.

Line: Some members of Pinto's congregation subsequently said they made tens of thousands of dollars in illegal contributions, including gifts passed through straw donors.

Line: Grimm has denied knowledge of any improprieties, and the FBI hasn't accused him of any wrongdoing.

Line: The Israeli businessman who had served as Grimm's liaison to Pinto's followers, Ofer Biton, pleaded guilty in August to an immigration fraud charge.

Line: Three days after that guilty plea, the FBI filed a sealed criminal complaint accusing a Houston woman who had been romantically involved with Grimm of using straw donors to make illegal campaign contributions.

Line: In that case, made public this month, the woman was accused of funneling at least $10,000 to Grimm's campaign by passing them through friends who agreed to have the donations listed under their names.

Line: A spokesman in Grimm's Washington office, Nick Iacono, did not immediately return emails or a telephone message seeking comment Friday.

Line: Rep. Michael Grimm (R-N.Y.) is expected to be indicted by the U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of New York, Grimm's lawyer said Friday.

Line: "We are disappointed by the government's decision, but hardly surprised," he said.

Line: The Justice Department began investigating Grimm two years ago on allegations that he filed erroneous campaign finance reports and accepted improper donations during his first congressional campaign.

Line: Representative Michael G. Grimm, a former F.B.I. agent and Marine who capitalized on his straight-arrow image to win a seat in Congress, was expected to be indicted on federal fraud charges after a lengthy corruption investigation, people with knowledge of the case said on Friday.
Label: Informational

Line: The charges against Mr. Grimm, 44, a Republican who was first elected in 2010 and represents Staten Island and part of Brooklyn, were expected to include mail fraud and wire fraud, and to focus largely on his conduct in connection with a health food restaurant he owned on the Upper East Side of Manhattan after he left the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 2006, two of the people said.
Label: Neutral

Line: He was also expected to be charged with obstruction of justice, for allegedly lying under oath in a federal lawsuit.
Label: Neutral

Line: The investigation of the second-term congressman, by the F.B.I. and the United States attorney's office in Brooklyn, began more than two years ago with an examination of Mr. Grimm's fund-raising for his 2010 race and expanded.
Label: Neutral

Line: Two of his fund-raisers have already been charged.
Label: Neutral

Line: One, Diana Durand of Houston, was charged with illegally funneling more than $10,000 into his campaign.
Label: Neutral

Line: The other, Ofer Biton, pleaded guilty to visa fraud charges.
Label: Neutral

Line: But on Friday, it did not appear that the indictment would include any campaign finance charges or accusations that the congressman had misused his office, although several of the people noted that the investigation was continuing.
Label: Neutral

Line: They all spoke on the condition of anonymity as the charges had not been formally announced and they were not authorized to discuss the case.
Label: Neutral

Line: A lawyer for Mr. Grimm, William McGinley of Patton Boggs, confirmed in a statement that prosecutors intended to file criminal charges against his client and said that Mr. Grimm  asserts his innocence  and that the investigation was  a politically driven vendetta.
Label: Neutral

Line: After more than two years of investigation plagued by malicious leaks, violations of grand jury secrecy and strong-arm tactics, the U.S. attorney's office has disclosed its intent to file criminal charges against Congressman Grimm,  Mr. McGinley said.
Label: Neutral

Line: When the dust settles, he will be vindicated.
Label: Neutral

Line: Until then, he will continue to serve his constituents with the same dedication and tenacity that has characterized his lifetime of public service as a member of Congress, Marine Corps combat veteran and decorated F.B.I. special agent.

Line: Spokesmen for the office of the United States attorney in Brooklyn, Loretta E. Lynch, and for the New York F.B.I. office declined to comment.

Line: Mr. Grimm, the only Republican member of New York City's congressional delegation, is up for re-election in November and faces a potentially formidable challenger in former City Councilman Domenic M. Recchia Jr., a Democrat who headed the Council's Finance Committee and was Christine C. Quinn's chief lieutenant when she was Council speaker.
Label: Neutral

Line: Healthalicious, the restaurant that the people said was a focus of the indictment, was on Second Avenue near 83rd Street.
Label: Neutral

Line: The company Mr. Grimm formed to operate it was called Granny Sayz, L.L.C., and was affiliated with a company connected to Mr. Biton, the fund-raiser.
Label: Neutral

Line: In January 2012, the New York State Workers' Compensation Board ordered Healthalicious to pay $88,000 for not carrying workers' compensation insurance.
Label: Neutral

Line: About a year earlier, two former deliverymen hired a lawyer who contacted Mr. Grimm's congressional office to complain that the restaurant had paid them less than minimum wage, did not pay for work beyond 40 hours per week and paid them in cash to evade scrutiny.
Label: Neutral

Line: Shortly afterward, Mr. Grimm filed papers with the state to dissolve Granny Sayz.
Label: Neutral

Line: The lawyer eventually sued Granny Sayz in federal court.
Label: Neutral

Line: Mr. Grimm over time developed something of a reputation for being hot-tempered, which did not set him apart from many others in Congress.
Label: Neutral

Line: But this year, during an encounter with a television reporter, he set a new standard for on-air congressional misbehavior and delivered a bizarre threat.
Label: Informational

Line: After President Obama's State of the Union address, NY1's Washington reporter, Michael Scotto, interviewed the congressman about the speech.
Label: Neutral

Line: When he asked about the federal campaign financing investigation, Mr. Grimm stormed off camera but returned and threatened to throw Mr. Scotto off the balcony.
Label: Lexical

Line: Then, the congressman, speaking in a barely audible whisper as he stood close to the reporter, said Mr. Scotto was  not man enough  and added:  I'll break you in half. Like a boy.
